elements.title: Peer Proof Card Visual Identity
elements.problem: When the platform introduces a norm-breaking term (like payment after first night instead of upfront at signing), the host needs immediate visual evidence that peers have accepted it. Currently, no distinct visual component exists for surfacing peer proof. Generic text explanations blend into the surrounding UI, giving the host no rapid way to distinguish 'what landlords like me have done' from 'what the platform is telling me.' John ignored the doubled deposit ($6,000 vs. $3,000) because it was presented as platform information, not peer-validated evidence. The visual system lacks a component that signals 'this is what someone like you experienced' at a glance.
elements.solution: Create a visually distinct peer proof card pattern that is immediately recognizable as 'evidence from a similar host' -- not platform marketing. The card uses a warm surface background (surface-warm token) with a left accent border in the forest green (accent token) to visually separate it from standard UI cards. The host's similarity markers (city, experience years) appear in mono font at the top, signaling data credibility. The outcome statement uses serif font for warmth and human voice. The card must be compact enough to scan in under 5 seconds and distinct enough to never be confused with a platform feature description or marketing callout.

evidence.quote: No, it wasn't no work. Like I said, you know, I've been in this business for a while and what we do in New York city as when you sign the lease, you give the checks.
evidence.insight: John's rejection is normative, not financial. He invokes collective NYC landlord behavior. A peer proof card must look and feel like evidence from that collective -- not like a platform sales pitch. The visual distinction between 'peer evidence' and 'platform information' must be immediate and unambiguous.

evidence.source: cialdini-social-proof.txt, Monkey Me Monkey Do section
evidence.quote: The principle of social proof operates most powerfully when we are observing the behavior of people just like us.
evidence.insight: Similarity markers must be the most visually prominent element on the proof card. The host's eye must land on 'NYC landlord, 10 years' before anything else, because similarity is what activates social proof processing. The visual hierarchy must enforce this: similarity first, outcome second, detail third.

evidence.source: cialdini-social-proof.txt, Truths Are Us section (wallet experiment)
evidence.quote: Only 33 percent of the wallets were returned when the first finder was seen as dissimilar, but fully 70 percent were returned when he was thought to be a similar other.
evidence.insight: The 70% vs. 33% gap means the visual treatment of similarity markers is not decorative -- it is the primary conversion lever. If the host cannot instantly identify the proof source as 'someone like me,' the card produces the 33% effect instead of the 70% effect.

IBM Plex Mono similarity markers in accent green on surface-warm background are legible at 12px due to the high contrast ratio.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye lands first on the green left-border accent (signals 'this is different from surrounding content'), then on the mono-set similarity markers at the top ('NYC landlord, 12 years'), then on the serif outcome statement ('received payment within 18 hours of check-in'), then on the sans-serif attribution. The left border creates an entry point; the mono text creates a credibility anchor; the serif text delivers the human story.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste-model.md principles: warm, not cold (surface-warm background, serif for human voice); trustworthy, not corporate (mono for data signals precision, not marketing); premium-accessible (the card feels high quality through restraint -- one accent color, three type treatments, no decoration). Forest green accent connects to trust/stability, not startup blue.

elements.title: Two-Layer Visual Separation for Tenant vs. Platform Information
elements.problem: Hosts evaluate tenant quality and platform terms through different trust frameworks, but the current visual flow presents both as undifferentiated information. John was cooperative when evaluating Ariel and Amber (02:12-03:50) but became resistant when platform payment terms arrived (05:40 onward). The shift happened because the two types of information looked and felt the same -- there was no visual signal that the host was transitioning from 'evaluating people' to 'evaluating a platform's terms.' Without visual separation, a negative reaction to platform terms contaminates the positive tenant evaluation because they exist in the same visual space.
elements.solution: Use visually distinct surface treatments to create two clear information layers. Layer A (Tenant Quality) uses the white surface token with standard card styling -- it feels familiar, like reviewing an application. Layer B (Platform Terms) uses the bg-deep token background with a distinct section header, creating a clear visual break that signals 'we are now discussing something different.' The transition between layers includes a visual confirmation moment: a summary bar with accent-light background that acknowledges the host's positive tenant evaluation before opening the platform terms layer. This ensures the positive impression is visually 'banked' before the potentially contentious information appears.

evidence.quote: And do they have a job here in New York city? [...] If you had the two different persons, I have one, a king sized bed and have another one, like a full size bed.
evidence.insight: John's cooperative tenant evaluation needed its own visual container. His positive assessment of the tenants was an asset -- it needed to be visually preserved as a completed, positive section before the platform terms arrived to potentially undermine it.

evidence.quote: They cannot pay just three months upfront [...] No, it wasn't no work.
evidence.insight: The stark behavioral shift at 05:40 maps to a visual design need: the host's eye and emotional state must be given a clear signal that the content type is changing. A surface color change, a section break, and a confirmation summary create the visual equivalent of the conversational pause that should have happened in the call.

evidence.quote: We view a behavior as more correct in a given situation to the degree that we see others performing it.
evidence.insight: Tenant evaluation uses familiar social proof (employment checks, credit checks are standard landlord behaviors). Platform terms use unfamiliar social proof (or none). Visually separating these layers allows each to carry its own evidence type: Layer A needs standard credential formatting; Layer B needs peer proof cards.

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Layer A occupies the primary visual position (top, white background, feels like the 'main' content). The transition confirmation bar serves as a visual checkpoint -- the eye recognizes a completed section. Layer B occupies the secondary position (below, deeper background, feels like a distinct context). The background color shift forces the eye to re-orient, preventing the host from processing Layer B on autopilot from Layer A.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste-model.md: warm, not cold (the bg-deep warm neutral creates a cozy second layer rather than a clinical gray). Confident, not flashy (the layer separation is achieved through subtle background shifts and spacing, not through borders, dividers, or decorative elements). The serif confirmation statement at the transition point adds human warmth at the moment of highest emotional vulnerability.

elements.title: Mono-Set Data Credibility Treatment for Trust Claims
elements.problem: When the platform makes data-backed claims -- payment guarantees, deposit amounts, credit check results -- they are presented in the same typographic voice as marketing copy and conversational explanation. John heard 'guaranteed payments,' '$6,000 deposit,' and 'credit checked' but none of these carried the visual weight of verified, institutional data. In his 12-year landlord experience, trustworthy financial information comes with a specific visual register: formal, precise, documented. Platform claims rendered in the same warm sans-serif as everything else feel like promises, not evidence. The visual system needs a way to signal 'this is verified data' distinct from 'this is a description.'
elements.solution: Use IBM Plex Mono for all data-backed trust claims: payment amounts, deposit figures, credit check status, guarantee terms, payment timing, and host outcome statistics. The mono typeface signals precision and institutional reliability -- it is the visual equivalent of fine print that is actually meant to be read. Pair the mono text with the accent green color for positive data (payment received, credit verified) and ink color for neutral data (amounts, dates). The mono treatment must be used selectively -- only for verified claims, never for marketing language -- so that its credibility signal remains potent.

evidence.quote: For the first month, rent that would get paid to you the day after the first night that they stayed, and for the security deposit, that's something split lease matches the security deposit. So you said you charged a 3000 deposit. Split lease would match that. So it would be 6,000, which we'd hold in total.
evidence.insight: These numbers -- $5,000/month, $3,000 deposit, $6,000 matched total, payment timing -- are the most consequential data points in the entire conversation. They need to look like data, not like conversation. Mono treatment visually separates factual claims from explanatory text, giving them the weight they carry in the host's decision.

evidence.quote: The only thing to request as well is a letter of employment, which is very important for me. And the credit, you said that you checked on that too.
evidence.insight: John treats employment verification and credit checks as formal, institutional data points -- not casual conversation. The visual treatment of these verification results must match the formality John expects: mono type, structured layout, clear pass/verified status indicators.

evidence.source: cialdini-social-proof.txt, Truths Are Us section (canned laughter research)
evidence.quote: Experiments have found that the use of canned merriment causes an audience to laugh longer and more often when humorous material is presented.
evidence.insight: Even transparently artificial signals change behavior because they operate on automatic processing. Mono typeface is a learned credibility signal -- we associate it with code, financial data, and verified records. Applying it to platform trust claims activates automatic credibility processing before the host has consciously evaluated the content.

The selective use of mono maintains its credibility signal -- if everything were mono, nothing would be. The accent green color for positive data connects to the trust/growth/stability associations defined in the color philosophy.

elements.title: Next Step Closure Card with Visual Urgency Hierarchy
elements.problem: When an interaction ends without resolution, the host enters limbo. John's call ended with 'I can talk to our team and see if that's something we can make an exception for' -- a statement with zero visual or structural weight. In a digital context, the equivalent failure is a page or screen that ends without a visually prominent, structured next-step block. The host scrolls past the end of the conversation or closes the tab, and there is no persistent visual artifact telling them who will do what, by when. Cialdini's bystander effect research shows that diffused responsibility + undefined timing = inaction. The visual system needs a closure component that is impossible to miss and impossible to misunderstand.
elements.solution: Design a Next Step Closure Card that uses visual urgency signals to ensure it is the last thing the host sees and the first thing they remember. The card uses a signal-info-bg background with a signal-info left border to distinguish it from all other card types (proof cards use accent green, standard cards use white). Inside, three structured rows use a rigid visual format: WHO (agent name, bold), WHAT (specific action, regular weight), WHEN (date/time, mono font in accent green for temporal precision). A fourth row shows the host's reciprocal action in a lighter treatment. The card is sticky on scroll or appears as a persistent footer element -- it never scrolls out of view on incomplete flows.

evidence.quote: Okay, I understand I can, when I'm going to do, I can talk to our team and see if that's something we can make an exception for.
evidence.insight: This closure statement has no visual equivalent that would persist in the host's memory. No name, no date, no specific action. The visual pattern must enforce the structure that the verbal interaction failed to provide: a card with mandatory fields (who, what, when) that cannot be rendered without specific content.

evidence.quote: Stare, speak, and point directly at that person and no one else: 'You, sir, in the blue jacket, I need help. Call an ambulance.'
evidence.insight: Cialdini's directed-action principle translates to visual design: the closure card must point at specific people with specific tasks. Bold treatment for the agent's name creates the visual equivalent of 'pointing at that person.' Mono treatment for the timeline creates the visual equivalent of a specific, non-negotiable deadline.

evidence.source: cialdini-social-proof.txt, Cause of Death: Uncertainty section
evidence.quote: When we are unsure of ourselves, when the situation is unclear or ambiguous, when uncertainty reigns, we are most likely to look to and accept the actions of others as correct.
evidence.insight: Uncertainty about next steps is the conversion killer. The visual pattern must reduce uncertainty to zero by making the next step so visually clear that the host cannot leave the interaction without knowing exactly what happens next. The sticky/persistent positioning ensures the card cannot be scrolled past or forgotten.

The signal-info blue is used sparingly in the system, which means this card type will be rare and therefore visually significant when it appears.

elements.title: Social Norm Framing Visual Hierarchy for Payment Terms
elements.problem: Payment terms are currently presented with financial data in the primary visual position: dollar amounts, percentages, deposit calculations. But John evaluated payment terms through a social norm lens, not a financial lens. He said 'I give him my apartment completely. I trust him and they get, trust me too' -- framing payment as mutual trust, not mathematics. When the visual hierarchy leads with numbers ($5,000, $6,000, 24 hours), the host processes the economics through their existing norm framework and rejects the deviation. The visual system places the wrong information first: it should lead with what similar hosts do, not with what the numbers are.
elements.solution: Restructure the visual hierarchy of all payment-related sections to follow a three-tier layout: (1) TOP: Social norm statement in serif font on a warm background -- 'How NYC hosts receive payment on Split Lease' -- establishing context before data. (2) MIDDLE: A peer proof card (using the looks-001 pattern) showing a specific similar host's experience with the payment model. (3) BOTTOM: The actual financial details in mono font with data pills, presented as supporting evidence for the norm, not as the primary content. This reversal ensures the host's eye encounters social framing before financial detail, activating the automatic social proof processing channel before the deliberate financial evaluation channel.

evidence.quote: Yeah. That's because, you know, I give him my apartment completely. I trust him and they get, trust me too.
evidence.insight: Payment is a trust signal for John, not a financial transaction. The visual hierarchy must reflect this: the trust dimension (what similar hosts experience) should be visually primary, and the financial dimension (exact amounts and timing) should be visually secondary. Currently, the financial detail occupies the primary visual position, which triggers John's norm-violation response before any social framing can take effect.

evidence.quote: Okay. Now you said that after the first night you got, I got to receive the payments. [...] Yeah, unfortunately, you know, I've been renting my apartment almost 12 years.
evidence.insight: John processed the payment timing ('after the first night') before any social evidence could contextualize it. His immediate response was to invoke his 12-year norm. If the visual hierarchy had presented peer evidence first and the payment timing second, his processing sequence would have been different: social evidence, then data, instead of data, then norm rejection.

evidence.source: cialdini-social-proof.txt, Truths Are Us section (canned laughter)
evidence.quote: In addition, some evidence indicates that canned laughter is most effective for poor jokes.
evidence.insight: Social proof is most effective when the underlying proposition is weakest. The payment-after-first-night model is the platform's 'weak joke' -- the term most likely to face resistance. This is exactly where social proof framing must be most visually prominent. The visual hierarchy should invest the most visual weight in social framing at the payment terms section, precisely because that is where resistance is highest.

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye reads top-to-bottom through three visually distinct tiers. Tier 1 (social norm) is the largest text on the warmest background -- it establishes context. Tier 2 (peer proof) is a visually distinct card with its own identity (green left border, mono similarity markers) -- it provides evidence. Tier 3 (financial detail) uses the most recessive background and smallest text -- it provides supporting data. The host processes social context before peer evidence before financial detail, which is the reverse of the current hierarchy and the correct sequence for norm-driven hosts.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste-model.md: 'Serif for personality (headlines, brand). Instrument Serif -- elegant but approachable.' Using serif for the social norm header connects the payment section to the brand's human, trustworthy voice rather than presenting it as a cold financial disclosure. The three-tier layout exemplifies 'confident, not flashy' -- no decorative elements, just clear visual hierarchy through type, size, and surface color.

elements.title: Progressive Disclosure Visual Rhythm for Payment Model Preview
elements.problem: The payment model -- the single most consequential piece of information for norm-driven hosts -- is introduced as a visual surprise deep in the flow. In John's call, 'guaranteed payments' was mentioned at 01:31 without timing detail, and the actual payment timing did not appear until 05:56. The visual equivalent is a landing page or email that mentions 'guaranteed payments' in a feature list without specifying the mechanism, followed by a detailed payment page deep in the flow that contradicts the host's assumed model. The visual system currently has no mechanism for previewing consequential information early and expanding it progressively. Each appearance of payment information looks identical regardless of its stage in the disclosure sequence.
elements.solution: Create a three-stage visual rhythm for payment information, where each stage has a distinct visual weight and density that signals its role in the progressive disclosure. Stage 1 (first touch -- email, landing page, first screen): A single-line preview in mono font with the timing included: 'Guaranteed payment within 24 hours of check-in.' This line appears as a compact data pill on an accent-light background, visually distinct from marketing copy but not expanded into a full section. Stage 2 (mid-conversation -- after positive tenant evaluation): A medium-density card with the social norm header, a peer proof card, and a one-sentence summary. Stage 3 (close or detail view): The full three-tier payment section from looks-005. Each stage visually builds on the previous one -- the mono data pill from Stage 1 reappears within Stage 2's card, and Stage 2's card reappears within Stage 3's full layout. This visual consistency means the host never encounters payment information that looks unfamiliar.

evidence.quote: We create the custom rental agreement and guaranteed payments to you as the landlord.
evidence.insight: Bryant's early mention of 'guaranteed payments' created a visual concept in John's mind: guaranteed = upfront, because that is his default. If the visual preview at first touch had included the timing ('within 24 hours of check-in') in a distinct, memorable mono treatment, John's mental model would have incorporated the timing from the start rather than defaulting to his norm.

evidence.quote: For the first month, rent that would get paid to you the day after the first night that they stayed.
evidence.insight: This is the first time the timing detail appears -- 4 minutes after the concept was introduced. The visual equivalent is a detail page that reveals information the host thought they already understood. Progressive disclosure prevents this by making each stage visually recognizable as a deeper layer of the same information, not a contradiction of earlier information.

evidence.source: cialdini-social-proof.txt, Cause of Death: Uncertainty section
evidence.quote: When we are unsure of ourselves, when the situation is unclear or ambiguous, when uncertainty reigns, we are most likely to look to and accept the actions of others as correct.
evidence.insight: Late, surprise disclosure maximizes uncertainty. Progressive visual disclosure minimizes it by giving the host time to absorb the concept at low density before encountering it at high density. Each visual stage reduces uncertainty incrementally rather than creating a single uncertainty spike.

The three-stage disclosure is journey-aware: it shows the right visual density at the right moment. It also aligns with 'confident, not flashy' -- the progressive reveal builds confidence through consistency rather than overwhelming with detail or underwhelming with vagueness.

elements.title: Similarity Badge System for Host-Matched Social Proof
elements.problem: When peer proof is surfaced, the host must instantly assess whether the proof source is similar enough to be credible. Cialdini's wallet experiment showed a 70% vs. 33% gap based on perceived similarity alone. Currently, there is no standardized visual component for communicating similarity dimensions -- city, experience years, property tier -- in a compact, scannable format. If similarity markers are buried in paragraph text or rendered in the same style as other content, the host must read and interpret them rather than scanning them instantly. The visual system needs a badge system that communicates 'this person is like you' at a glance.
elements.solution: Create a compact similarity badge row that sits at the top of every peer proof card. Each badge is a pill-shaped element with a mono label on an accent-light background. Standard badge categories: location (e.g., 'NYC'), experience (e.g., '12 yr'), property tier (e.g., '$5K/mo'). The badges are visually identical in style regardless of content, creating a scannable pattern that the host learns to recognize across multiple proof cards. When a badge dimension matches the host's own profile, it receives a stronger visual treatment: accent background with white text instead of accent-light background with accent text. This match-highlighting ensures the host sees similarity without having to compare mentally.

evidence.quote: I've been renting my apartment almost 12 years, back and forth.
evidence.insight: John's 12 years of experience is his identity anchor. A similarity badge showing '12 yr' on a proof card from an NYC landlord with similar tenure would be the visual equivalent of Cialdini's 'similar other.' The badge must be immediately scannable -- the host should not have to read a sentence to discover the similarity.

evidence.source: cialdini-social-proof.txt, Monkey Me Monkey Do section
evidence.quote: The principle of social proof operates most powerfully when we are observing the behavior of people just like us.
evidence.insight: Similarity is not a detail -- it is the primary lever. The visual treatment must reflect this: similarity badges should be the first thing the eye lands on within a proof card. They are not metadata; they are the headline.

evidence.source: cialdini-social-proof.txt, Truths Are Us section (Bandura shy children research)
evidence.quote: The most effective type of clips were those depicting not one but a variety of other children interacting with their dogs.
evidence.insight: Multiple proof cards with consistent similarity badges create a pattern: the host sees badge after badge confirming 'NYC, 10+ yr, $5K+' and the cumulative effect is stronger than any single testimonial. The badge system must be visually consistent across all proof cards so that the pattern is recognizable.

colors: accent-light (#e8f0eb) for default badge background (non-matched dimensions)
accent (#2d5a3d) for default badge text
accent (#2d5a3d) as solid background for matched-dimension badges
surface (#ffffff) for text on matched-dimension badges
border (#e2dfd9) for subtle badge border on default state
typography: IBM Plex Mono, weight 500, text-xs (11px) for badge labels -- mono signals data, xs size keeps badges compact
Letter-spacing: 0.5px for badge text to improve legibility at small sizes
spacing: xs (4px) horizontal padding inside each badge
xs (4px) gap between badges in the row
sm (8px) margin below the badge row, separating it from the proof card content
new_tokens_needed: badge-matched-bg: accent (#2d5a3d) solid -- a filled badge state for dimensions that match the current host's profile, creating immediate visual recognition of similarity
badge-default-bg: accent-light (#e8f0eb) -- the standard unfilled badge state

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Default badges: accent (#2d5a3d) text on accent-light (#e8f0eb) background at approximately 5.2:1, passing AA at 11px (which requires 4.5:1 for normal text). Matched badges: surface (#ffffff) text on accent (#2d5a3d) background at approximately 6.5:1, comfortably passing AA. The matched badge inversion (white on green vs. green on light green) creates a clear visual signal of similarity match without requiring the host to read and compare the values.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Within a proof card, the eye lands on the badge row first because the pills create a distinct horizontal pattern at the top of the card. Matched badges (filled green) draw attention before default badges (light green) because of their higher visual weight. The host's scan path is: matched badges (instant similarity recognition), then default badges (additional context), then the proof outcome below. The badge system turns similarity assessment from a reading task into a pattern-recognition task.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste-model.md: 'Mono for data/trust (prices, stats, badges). IBM Plex Mono signals precision and reliability.' The badge system extends the mono-for-data principle to similarity markers, treating host demographics as verified data points rather than marketing descriptors. The pill shape with rounded-full radius aligns with 'trustworthy, not corporate' -- rounded corners signal approachability while the mono font signals precision. The accent green color maintains the trust/stability associations from the color philosophy.
